LEAD: Much of the concern about acid rain has focussed on the vulnerable lakes of the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York, where fish life has disappeared from some waters.But a new survey of available information on 160 lakes in the Pocono Mountain region of Pennsylvania has shown that many lakes there, too, are vulnerable.

Much of the concern about acid rain has focussed on the vulnerable lakes of the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York, where fish life has disappeared from some waters.But a new survey of available information on 160 lakes in the Pocono Mountain region of Pennsylvania has shown that many lakes there, too, are vulnerable. According to the survey, 7.5 percent of the lakes are already acidified and more than 70 percent are ''sensitive,'' to damage from acid rain.

Particularly hard hit are small lakes at high elevations; 30 percent of lakes covering less than 50 acres at elevations of more than 1,640 feet above sea level are already acidified, according to the survey.

The conclusions are based on data obtained from Federal, state and private agencies by Patricia T. Bradt and Linda Wimpfheimer of the Environmental Studies Center of Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa. Acidic precipitation is chiefly caused by pollution from sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides from smokestacks and autos. The pollutants can be transformed in the atmosphere into acids that fall to earth.
